newsitem.title: GREECE: ECU/DRACHMA SEEN STABLE, AROUND 305 IN 97-SALOMON.
newsitem.headline: ECU/DRACHMA SEEN STABLE, AROUND 305 IN 97-SALOMON.

text.p: Salomon Brothers expects the drachma to remain broadly stable in 1997 with ecu/drachma settling around 305 on average but be more volatile day-to-day to discourage capital inflows, it said in its February debt strategy report.
"The drachma should remain approximately stable at around ecu/drachma 305 on average in 1997 but the ecu/drachma is likely to be more volatile," it said in its February 24 report.
The monetary authorities appear to have set an implicit fluctuation band for the drachma and plan to refrain from intra-marginal intervention within this band, it said.
The sustainability of the exchange rate depended on the pace of fiscal consolidation and wage growth, it said.
However, Salomon saw currency risks because of "historically low real yields and the slowdown of disinflation.." in its January 21 report.
The central bank seems to be currently placing more emphasis on combating inflation and containing debt service costs over trade deficit considerations, it added.
The current account deficit is projected to decline in 1997 after peaking at just over $4.0 billion or 3.75 percent of GDP in 1996.
Revised balance of payments statistics based on the standard resident/non-resident breakdown from the local/foreign currency breakdown of transactions will account for the improvement.
Salomon Brothers which recommended a neutral position on Greek bonds in its late January report said falling T-bill yields would level off in coming weeks.

"After a rapid decline to just under 11 percent at end-January, the 12-month Treasury bill rate will probably level off in coming weeks while remaining sufficiently high to sustain interest in fixed-income local currency instruments," it said. --Dimitris Kontogiannis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
